name: Categorical Logic
long_desc: This course focuses on applications of category theory in logic and computer science. A leading idea is functorial semantics, according to which a model of a logical theory is a setvalued functor on a category determined by the theory. This gives rise to a syntaxinvariant notion of a theory and introduces many algebraic methods into logic, leading naturally to the universal and other general models that distinguish functorial from classical semantics. Such categorical models occur, for example, in denotational semantics. e.g. treating the lambdacalculus via the theory of cartesian closed categories. Higherorder logic is treated categorically by the theory of topoi. We shall see how this idea connects logic with topology the models of a theory form a space. A prerequisite for this course is familiarity with basic category theory as treated in the course 80413713.

custom_fields.goals: Understand models of logical theories in categories of objects other than sets.
custom_fields.key_topics: Category theory, semantics of logical theories, relations between logic and topology
custom_fields.assessment_structure: Weekly homework, final exam, in class presentations
custom_fields.relevance: Interactions between logic, category theory, and topology have become fundamental in the three fields.
